titleText.ttltext: Do grandparents influence parents’ decision to @hit_startvaccinate@hit_end their children? A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end

organizations: School of Medical and Health Sciences, Edith Cowan University

paras: The global reduction in childhood infectious diseases since the 1960s is primarily due to the success of extensive worldwide @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end campaigns. However, the universal @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage program appears to have lost momentum in the wake of negative, unfounded claims about the safety of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. While parents of the 21st century have little first-hand knowledge of devastating childhood diseases, grandparents are more likely to remember family and community members who were afflicted. In the current age of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end hesitancy and science scepticism, where research-informed arguments are not always persuasive, grandparents, through their experience of the diseases, may positively influence paediatric @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake. This paper @hit_startreviews@hit_end the @hit_startliterature@hit_end investigating potential direct or indirect influences of grandparents on parents’ decisions to @hit_startvaccinate@hit_end their children. A database search using the keywords @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end, @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, children and grandparents resulted in 1988 articles. Titles were screened for relevance and seventy-seven results were retained. After the abstracts were read, only five articles that either explored paediatric @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, factors promoting and/or inhibiting paediatric @hit_startvaccine@hit_end use and decision-making strategies were reviewed. One paper located through Google Scholar, which failed to show up on database searches, was also retained for a total of six papers. While none of the six papers set out to explore the impact of grandparents on @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake, they found that grandparents were involved to varying degrees in paediatric @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake within young families. The research clearly showing that grandparents, and older people more generally, promote @hit_startvaccination@hit_end uptake is not currently available. The dearth of literature shows the need for research exploring the perceived and real influences of grandparents on childhood @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. This will establish whether grandparents’ memory and knowledge of preventable childhood infectious diseases could be harnessed as a public health measure to counteract the current, ill-informed, negative attention on paediatric @hit_startvaccines@hit_end.

titleText.ttltext: Understanding barriers and predictors of maternal @hit_startimmunization@hit_end: Identifying gaps through an exploratory @hit_startliterature review@hit_end

organizations: @hit_startImmunization@hit_end Services Division, National Center for @hit_startImmunization@hit_end and Respiratory Diseases, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

paras: Background: The Advisory Committee for @hit_startImmunization@hit_end Practices recommends that all pregnant women receive the seasonal influenza @hit_startvaccine@hit_end and the tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) @hit_startvaccine@hit_end during every pregnancy. However, @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage rates are suboptimal among pregnant women in the United States, leaving these women and their unborn children at risk of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end@hit_start-preventable@hit_end diseases and their complications. Objectives: We sought to understand the current landscape of published literature regarding maternal @hit_startimmunization@hit_end, including barriers to and predictors of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end acceptance, and identify gaps in the research in order to inform strategies for future programmatic improvement. Methods: We conducted a literature search using @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end (OVID), @hit_startPsychINFO@hit_end, and @hit_startCINAHL@hit_end (Ebsco) databases. The search included published, English-language manuscripts that identified patient, provider, or system-level barriers to, predictors of, or interventions that improved uptake of maternal @hit_startvaccines@hit_end among pregnant women in the US. Studies were reviewed using an inductive thematic @hit_startanalysis@hit_end approach. Results: We included 75 studies in our review. Pregnant women identified 25 different barriers to accepting recommended maternal immunizations; barriers related to @hit_startvaccine@hit_end safety perceptions were the most common. Healthcare providers identified 24 different barriers to @hit_startvaccinating@hit_end their pregnant patients. The most commonly cited barriers among healthcare providers were financial concerns. Eighteen different predictors of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end acceptance were identified. Receipt of a healthcare provider's recommendation was the factor most frequently reported as a reason for @hit_startvaccination@hit_end among pregnant women. Conclusions: We were able to identify gaps in the literature regarding maternal @hit_startimmunization@hit_end and make recommendations for future research. Efforts to address the challenges of maternal @hit_startimmunization@hit_end in the United States should include increasing the focus on Tdap, implementing more high-level assessments of safety perceptions and associated concerns, and determining most effective interventions.

titleText.ttltext: Impact of the Hajj on pneumococcal carriage and the effect of various pneumococcal @hit_startvaccines@hit_end

paras: Background: The Islamic Hajj pilgrimage is the largest annual mass gathering in the world. The overcrowding of people promotes the acquisition, spread and transmission of respiratory pathogens, including Streptococcus pneumoniae. Methods: We conducted a methodological review according to the Preferred Reporting Items for @hit_startSystematic Reviews@hit_end and @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-Analysis@hit_end guidelines. The objective was to summarize the available data regarding the prevalence of pneumococcal carriage among Hajj pilgrims and about carriage acquisition and circulation of S. pneumoniae among pilgrims before and after participating in the Hajj according to their @hit_startvaccination@hit_end status. Results: Eight articles met eligibility criteria for pneumococcal carriage and impact of pneumococcal @hit_startvaccination@hit_end on carriage. Seven of them showed a significant increase in nasopharyngeal carriage of pneumococci following the pilgrimage, with acquisition rates ranging from 18 to 36%. Serotypes 3, 19F and 34 are the most common. A significant increase in antibiotic resistant strains was observed following participation in the Hajj. A lower prevalence was found in pilgrims treated with antibiotics, those who used a hand sanitizer, or those who washed their hands more frequently than usual. An increased carriage of pneumococcal serotypes included in pneumococcal @hit_startvaccines@hit_end (10-valent pneumococcal conjugate @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (PCV10), 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (PCV13), 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (PPV23)) was observed following participation in the Hajj. To date, no study has shown a significant reduction in pneumococcal carriage among pilgrims after @hit_startvaccination@hit_end with PPV23 or PCV. In fact, no significant difference was currently observed in the prevalence ratio of pneumococcal carriage between @hit_startvaccinated@hit_end and unvaccinated pilgrims. Conclusion: The studies @hit_startanalyzed@hit_end in this review showed an increased carriage of pneumococcus in post-Hajj pilgrims compared to pre-Hajj pilgrims, including @hit_startvaccine@hit_end serotypes. Further studies are needed to investigate the possible relationships between carriage, disease and @hit_startvaccine@hit_end in pilgrims.

titleText.ttltext: Influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage of population and the factors influencing influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in mainland China: A @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Epidemiology and Health Statistics, Southeast University, Southeast University

paras: Introduction: The best way to prevent influenza is receiving @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. However, the influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage in mainland China was low. A @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end was conducted to estimate the @hit_startvaccination@hit_end rates of the population and the factors influencing influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in mainland China. Methods: A systematic study was conducted on March 18, 2018, using Chinese language databases including China National Knowledge Infrastructure, Chinese Science and Technology Periodical Database, WanFang Database, and English language databases including @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, Web of Science, and @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Library. Based on the inclusion and exclusion criteria, the pooled coverage rate and estimated odds ratios (OR) of influencing factors were obtained using data abstraction. Subgroup @hit_startanalysis@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end-regression @hit_startanalysis@hit_end were also employed to explore the heterogeneity. Results: The pooled @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage rate in 126 included articles was 23.2% (95% confidence interval (CI): 22.8%, 23.7%), and the pooled @hit_startvaccination@hit_end rate among the general population was 9.4% (95% CI: 8.0%, 10.9%). The influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end rate fluctuated from 2005 to 2017. @hit_startVaccination@hit_end rates in 2009–2010 were much higher than other years, pandemic influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end rate was 37.3% (95% CI: 28.4%, 46.1%) and seasonal influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end rate was 29.8% (95% CI: 24.6%, 34.9%). In the @hit_startanalysis@hit_end of influencing factors, those recommended by healthcare workers was the most reported reasons for influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end with an OR = 5.2 (95% CI: 2.9, 9.4), and following as received influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end previously, perceived safety of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, perceived effectiveness of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, perceived severity of the disease. @hit_startMeta@hit_end-regression @hit_startanalysis@hit_end indicate that the heterogeneity maybe significantly consistent with the sample size, study population, study region, and @hit_startvaccination@hit_end policy. Conclusion: Compared with other countries (the United States), @hit_startvaccination@hit_end rates were lower in mainland China. There were a few factors influencing the rate, which included @hit_startvaccination@hit_end policy, @hit_startvaccination@hit_end history and knowledge and attitudes toward influenza and @hit_startvaccination@hit_end.

titleText.ttltext: Prevention of cervical cancer in HIV-seropositive women from developing countries through cervical cancer screening: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end

organizations: School of Health Systems and Public Health, Epidemiology and Biostatistics, University of Pretoria, 5-10 H.W. Snyman Building

paras: Background: There is scanty or inconclusive evidence on which cervical cancer screening tool is effective and suitable for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-seropositive women. The aim of this review was to assess, synthesise and document published evidence relating to the available cervical cancer screening modalities for HIV-seropositive women in developing countries. This paper did not review the issue of human papillomavirus (HPV) prophylactic @hit_startvaccine@hit_end on HIV-seropositive women. Methods: Five electronic databases were systematically searched from inception to January 2018 for relevant published original research examining cervical cancer prevention modalities for HPV infection, abnormal cytology and direct visualisation of the cervix amongst HIV-seropositive women in developing countries. Extra studies were identified through reference list and citation tracking. Results: Due to methodological and clinical heterogeneity, a narrative synthesis was presented. Of the 2559 articles, 149 underwent full-text screening and 25 were included in the review. Included studies were of moderate quality, and no exclusions were made based on quality or bias. There is no standard cervical cancer screening test or programme for HIV-seropositive women and countries screening according to available resources and expertise. The screening methods used for HIV-seropositive women are the same for HIV-negative women, with varying clinical performance and accuracy. The main cervical cancer screening methods described for HIV-seropositive women are HPV deoxyribonucleic acid/messenger RNA (DNA/mRNA) testing (n = 16, 64.0%), visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA) (n = 13, 52.0%) and Pap smear (n = 11, 44.0%). HPV testing has a better accuracy/efficiency than other methods with a sensitivity of 80.0-97.0% and specificity of 51.0-78.0%. Sequential screening using VIA or visual inspection with Lugol's iodine (VILI) and HPV testing has shown better clinical performance in screening HIV-seropositive women. Conclusion: Although cervical cancer screening exists in almost all developing countries, what is missing is both opportunistic and systematic organised population-based screenings. Cervical cancer screening programmes need to be integrated into already existing HIV services to enable early detection and treatment. There is a need to offer opportunistic and coordinated screening programmes that are provider-initiated to promote early identification of cervical precancerous lesions. @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end registration: PROSPERO CRD42018095702

titleText.ttltext: The unsolved problem of otitis media in indigenous populations: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of upper respiratory and middle ear microbiology in indigenous children with otitis media

organizations: Faculty of Medicine, University of Queensland

paras: Background: Otitis media (OM) imposes a great burden of disease in indigenous populations around the world, despite a variety of treatment and prevention programs. Improved understanding of the pathogenesis of OM in indigenous populations is required to advance treatment and reduce prevalence. We conducted a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of the @hit_startliterature@hit_end exploring the upper airway and middle ear microbiota in relation to OM in indigenous children. Methods: Papers targeting microbiota in relation to OM in children < 18 years indigenous to Australia, New Zealand, North America, and Greenland were sought. @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, @hit_startCINAHL@hit_end, @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Library, and Informit databases were searched using key words. Two independent reviewers screened titles, abstracts, and then full-text papers against inclusion criteria according to PRISMA guidelines. Results: Twenty-five papers considering indigenous Australian, Alaskan, and Greenlandic children were included. There were high rates of nasopharyngeal colonization with the three main otopathogens (Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Moraxella catarrhalis) in indigenous children with OM. Middle ear samples had lower rates of otopathogen detection, although detection rates increased when molecular methods were used. Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus were commonly detected in middle ear discharge of children with chronic suppurative OM. There was a significant heterogeneity between studies, particularly in microbiological methods, which were largely limited to culture-based detection of the main otopathogens. Conclusions: There are high rates of otopathogen colonization in indigenous children with OM. Chronic suppurative OM appears to be associated with a different microbial profile. Beyond the main otopathogens, the data are limited. Further research is required to explore the entire upper respiratory tract/middle ear microbiota in relation to OM, with the inclusion of healthy indigenous peers as controls.

organizations: Faculty of Medicine and Health, Leeds Institute of Health Sciences, University of Leeds

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: To evaluate the potential economic value and likely impact of a hypothetical rapid test in its early stages of development requires the use of models. The model structure and the type of model (dynamic/static) to employ are key considerations. The aim of the review was to explore the literature on typhoid economic evaluations and to explore the types of models that have been previously adopted in this setting for test-treat evaluations and to capture data on model inputs that may be useful for a de novo model. Areas covered: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end was conducted to identify economic evaluations focused on typhoid in established literature databases. Eight studies were identified and included for narrative synthesis. The review has revealed that there have been relatively few economic evaluations that have focused on typhoid fever, all of which have focused on the impact of interventions at the population level (@hit_startvaccination@hit_end) but not the individual level (test-treat strategies). Expert commentary: Under certain circumstances, either a static model or a transmission dynamic model may be appropriate in the evaluation of an intervention for typhoid fever. Typhoid test-treat modeling represents a gray area where further work is needed.

sourceTitle: Expert Review of Pharmacoeconomics and Outcomes Research

titleText.ttltext: Update: Recommendations of the Advisory Committee on @hit_startImmunization@hit_end Practices for Use of Hepatitis A @hit_startVaccine@hit_end for Postexposure Prophylaxis and for Preexposure Prophylaxis for International Travel

paras: Postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) with hepatitis A (HepA) @hit_startvaccine@hit_end or immune globulin (IG) effectively prevents infection with hepatitis A virus (HAV) when administered within 2 weeks of exposure. Preexposure prophylaxis against HAV infection through the administration of HepA @hit_startvaccine@hit_end or IG provides protection for unvaccinated persons traveling to or working in countries that have high or intermediate HAV endemicity. The Advisory Committee on @hit_startImmunization@hit_end Practices (ACIP) Hepatitis @hit_startVaccines@hit_end Work Group conducted a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of the evidence for administering @hit_startvaccine@hit_end for PEP to persons aged >40 years and reviewed the HepA @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efficacy and safety in infants and the benefits of protection against HAV before international travel. The February 21, 2018, ACIP recommendations update and supersede previous ACIP recommendations for HepA @hit_startvaccine@hit_end for PEP and for international travel. Current recommendations include that HepA @hit_startvaccine@hit_end should be administered to all persons aged ≥12 months for PEP. In addition to HepA @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, IG may be administered to persons aged >40 years depending on the provider's risk assessment. ACIP also recommended that HepA @hit_startvaccine@hit_end be administered to infants aged 6-11 months traveling outside the United States when protection against HAV is recommended. The travel-related dose for infants aged 6-11 months should not be counted toward the routine 2-dose series. The dosage of IG has been updated where applicable (0.1 mL/kg). HepA @hit_startvaccine@hit_end for PEP provides advantages over IG, including induction of active @hit_startimmunity@hit_end, longer duration of protection, ease of administration, and greater acceptability and availability.

titleText.ttltext: Synthetic therapeutics for the treatment of hepatitis B during pregnancy

organizations: Department of Gastroenterology and Hepatology, Max Super Speciality Hospital, Vaishali

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: Hepatitis B infection in pregnancy mandates careful monitoring and specialized management according to the phase of hepatitis B infection. Perinatal transmission may be prevented by antiviral therapy in mothers with high viral load and timely immunoprophylaxis of the infant. Areas covered: This review focuses on the current first-line therapies for treating hepatitis B in pregnancy, timing of therapy, and prevention of perinatal transmission. Strategies to manage disease at the various phases and potential emerging therapies in phase III of development are also covered. @hit_startMedline@hit_end/@hit_startPubMed@hit_end and @hit_startCochrane@hit_end databases were searched systematically from 1990 to April 2018 with the relevant articles selected for the review. Expert opinion Universal antenatal screening for hepatitis B and strict immunoprophylaxis for infants form the cornerstones to prevent hepatitis B virus (HBV) perinatal transmission. Tenofovir is the preferred drug for treatment in pregnancy in view of its good efficacy and high barrier to resistance. Most of the data on antivirals are from cohort studies which are prone to bias and more randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are needed to establish the benefits and safety of these drugs in pregnancy. Various novel drugs are in the pipeline which may pave the way for a cure in the near future.

titleText.ttltext: Understanding the role of exogenous boosting in modeling varicella @hit_startvaccination@hit_end

affiliation.addressPart: Merck Sharp & Dohme Corp., 1 Merck Dr, Whitehouse Station

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: The exogenous boosting (EB) hypothesis posits that cell-mediated @hit_startimmunity@hit_end is boosted for individuals reexposed to varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Historically, mathematical models of the impact of universal childhood varicella @hit_startvaccination@hit_end (UVV) have used limited data to capture EB and often conclude that UVV will temporarily increase herpes zoster (HZ) incidence. Areas covered: We updated a 2013 @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end of 40 studies to summarize new evidence from observational or modeling studies related to EB and its parameterization. We abstracted data on observational study designs and mathematical model structures, EB frameworks, and HZ-related parameter values. Expert commentary: This review identified an additional 41 studies: 22 observational and 19 modeling studies. Observational @hit_startanalyses@hit_end generally reported pre-UVV increases in HZ incidence, making it difficult to attribute post-UVV increases to UVV versus other causes. Modeling studies considered a range of EB frameworks, from no boosting to full permanent @hit_startimmunity@hit_end. Mathematical modeling efforts are needed in countries with long-standing @hit_startvaccination@hit_end programs to capture the dynamics of VZV transmission and temporal changes that may affect HZ incidence. Use of real-world pre-/postvaccination data on varicella and HZ incidence to validate model predictions may improve approaches to EB parameterization and understanding of the effects of varicella @hit_startvaccination@hit_end programs.
